column2: The Macedonian Revolution
The Macedonian Revolution

For centuries, the Greek and Bulgarian population of Macedonia has endured the harsh and capricious rule of the Sultan. Sensing an opportunity to increase their international standing and bring about the downfall of their rival, Venice and Aragon helped us organise our revolution. The Conference of Naples was held to that end in the year 1824. Now we have risen against the Turk, but the fight will be a hard one and thousands will die. The assurances of the foreign powers are an inadequate protection against Ottoman bullets. We must press Venice and Aragon to join our war.
Send delegations to them at once.
Macedonia Calls for Help

Sensing an opportunity to increase our international standing, we fuelled the flames of rebellion in the Ottoman Empire. $COUNTRY_ADJ$ diplomats were instrumental in convincing Greek and Bulgarian revolutionaries in Macedonia to rise up and overthrow the Ottoman yoke. Now, the revolutionaries are calling out for us to aid them in their war, as we promised at the Conference of Naples in 1824.
We will honour our commitments!
We must have given them the wrong impression.
$FROMCOUNTRY$ Agrees to Help
$FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ diplomats have given the Macedonian provisional government the strongest assurances that they intend to aid us in our War of Independence.
That is excellent news.
$FROMCOUNTRY$ Refuses to Help

Our envoys in $FROMCOUNTRY$ have failed in their quest to secure an anti-Ottoman alliance with $FROMCOUNTRY$. The $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ government has apologised profusely, but they claim we must have misunderstood the extent to which they were willing to provide support.
An outrage!
Calling our Allies
Having secured international support for our cause, it is time to test the seriousness of our allies. The war effort necessitates their direct military involvement.
To arms, citizens!
Macedonia is Free!

Our War of Independence has ended, and Macedonia has gained her hard-earned freedom. Greeks and Bulgars can rejoice, for it is a glorious day when the Macedonian tricolour flies proudly over the land of Alexander.
Long Live!
Macedonia is Free!

The Macedonian War of Independence has ended, and our newest ally has gained their hard-earned freedom. Greeks and Bulgars can rejoice, for it is a glorious day when the Macedonian tricolour flies proudly over the land of Alexander.
Long Live!
We Failed Macedonia

When the great military powers of the world make commitments, they are expected to keep them. We promised Macedonia aid in their war of independence, but we have failed to come to their aid. This reflects badly on us and we likely have lost much leverage over Macedonia.
A shameful display.
We Failed Macedonia

When the great military powers of the world make commitments, they are expected to keep them. We promised Macedonia aid in their war of independence, but we have failed to come to their aid. This reflects badly on us and we likely have lost much leverage over Macedonia. What hope there was of prince Martin Fernando Alfonso of the royal house of Aragon acceding to a new Macedonian throne has been swept away by our diplomatic ineptitude. The throne will now most likely go to another European monarchy.
It's still early in the game, maybe restart?
Macedonia Lost!
The Macedonian War of Independence has ended, and we have lost one of our most important provinces. This is a monumental loss for $COUNTRY$, and Mehmed is surely turning in his grave.
Dark days lie ahead.
The Fate of the Republic

In helping us gain our independence, Aragon made it abundantly clear at the Conference of Naples in 1824 that they were only interested in aiding us if we agreed to place prince Martín Fernando Alfonso de Trastámara, Prince of Aragon, on the Macedonian throne under a system of constitutional monarchy. The war now at an end, the Constitutional Convention assembled at $CAPITAL$ must decide the fate of the country. Defy Aragon and the other monarchies of Europe and risk war to subdue republicanism, or accept their demands and abolish the republic?
Well, they did promise a *constitutional* monarchy...
We will press ahead with a more democratic republic.
The government needs no reform.
The Fate of the Republic

We have gained our independence at a time when monarchy is the prevailing form of government on the continent. Our republic is a republic in name only, power residing in a small circle of intellectuals leading the Revolution. The war now at an end, the Constitutional Convention assembled at $CAPITAL$ must decide the fate of the country. Anger the other monarchies of Europe and risk war to subdue republicanism, or accept their demands and abolish the republic?
We must not anger the Great Powers. Constitutional monarchy!
We will press ahead with a more democratic republic.
The government needs no reform.
The Crown of Macedonia

In helping Macedonia gain her independence, we made it abundantly clear that we were only interested in aiding them if they agreed to place prince Martín Fernando Alfonso de Trastámara, Prince of Aragon, on the Macedonian throne under a system of constitutional monarchy. The war now at an end, the Constitutional Convention assembled in $FROMCOUNTRY_CAPITAL$ has decided to offer Martín Fernando Alfonso the crown, as agreed at the Conference of Naples in 1824.
He obviously accepts.
We have no interest in the crown from the gutter!
The Kingdom of Macedonia

Martín Fernando Alfonso de Trastámara, Prince of Aragon, has accepted our proposal that he ascend the Macedonian throne. All preparations are in place for him to be coronated in $CAPITAL$. What should his regal name be? Alexander seems fitting.
Long Live the King!
Martín Fernando Alfonso Refuses

In a truly surreal turn of events, upon hearing that our Constitutional Convention has agreed to abolish the republic and apoint him King of Macedonia within a constitutional framework, prince Martín Fernando Alfonso of Aragon flat-out refused the offer. The words 'crown from the gutter' were allegedly uttered, though the royal household has refused to comment.
To avoid war, we must find another prince.
A democratic republic is the only logical course of action.
Why not maintain the current junta?
The Macedonian Republic

The Constitutional Convention concluded its workings today, and a new Constitution was signed. Macedonia is to be a democratic republic, built on principles of equality and brotherhood, a true role model for the peoples of the world still living under barbarously illiberal monarchies. Said monarchies will probably not take too kindly to our little experiment, however.
Three hurrahs for the republic!
The Crown of Macedonia

The newly-independent state of Macedonia has decided to reform its revolutionary government into a constitutional monarchy so as not to anger the monarchial powers of Europe. The Constitutional Convention has decided to offer one of our princes the new crown of Macedonia.
Any excuse to further our influence.
We have no interest in a third-rate crown.
The Kingdom of Macedonia

$FROMCOUNTRY$ has accepted our proposal that a $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ prince acceed the Macedonian throne. All preparations are in place for a grand coronation in $CAPITAL$. What should his regal name be? Alexander seems fitting.
Long Live the King!
New Republic on the Block

Macedonia has embarked on a risky little experiment, instituting a democratic republic - in direct opposition to our insistance on a constitutional monarchy instead. This is an extremely dangerous precedent, and as a Great Power built on a tradition of monarchial legitimacy, we must respond with an iron fist.
Macedonia *will* be a monarchy.
Let them be, we have more pressing issues.
New Republic on the Block

Macedonia, having thrown off the chains of Ottoman domination, has decided to reform its government into that of a democratic republic. Being a republic ourselves, we know that the other Great Powers don't look favourably on republicanism. It is certain that they will seek to turn Macedonia into a monarchy. Should we take the moral decision and ally ourselves with the nascent Macedonian republic, or let them fend for themselves?
We shall stand with them.
Let them be, we have more pressing issues.
The Great Fire of Thessalonica

The city of Thessalonica, in $COUNTRY$, the most cosmopolitan city in the Balkans, at one time the second city of the Eastern Roman Empire, has experienced what is perhaps the worst disaster in its 2,300-year history. A city fire began in a small kitchen in the Ottoman-era Upper Town and soon spread through the ancient city, aided by strong winds, destroying the Ottoman and more modern European parts of the city alike. Firefighting was made especially difficult by an ongoing drought. Experts describe the fire as most devastating of its kind in Europe for at least a century, comapring it to the Great Fire of London in terms of magnitude, as it has destroyed huge swathes of the city - early reports indicate more than 50% of the city centre - while leaving thousands homeless and unemployed. Many of the city's ancient churches, Ottoman mosques, and one-third of its 33 synagogues, were destroyed by the blaze. City authorities, aided by international military crews stationed nearby, have managed to contain the fire, but the true scale of the fire remains to be surveyed.
A true loss for the Balkans.
Surveying the Damage

The blaze in Thessalonica has been contained, and local authorities, aided by the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ government, have began to survey the damage. The contents of the report they produced are disturbing. The beloved 'Bride of the Thermaic Gulf' has been very badly damaged. The city centre was hardest-hit, with 4,000 buildings destroyed and 35,000 left homeless. The city's Jewish community, once the only European Jewish community to form a majority of the population in a European city, has been especially hard-hit. The port and the docks has been spared, but large parts of the so-called 'Frankish quarter', containing the banking and insurance industries, has been destroyed. The National Bank of $COUNTRY$ and its reserves has also been destroyed, as well as the central post office. The city council building miraculously survived as everythinga round it was burnt to the ground. The government estimates the total damage caused to be 5 million gold pounds. The report does, however, contain some praise for $COUNTRY$'s strict safety regulations, which the authors stress were instrumental in containing the blaze to the degree that it was possible.
The horror!

The government estimates the total damage caused to be 9 million gold pounds. The report also stressed the need to further strengthen $COUNTRY$'s safety regulations, which the authors stress were would have spared much of the city.
The horror!

The contents of the report they produced are truly unbelievable - the extent of the damage is beyong anything we could have imagined. The beloved 'Bride of the Thermaic Gulf' does not exist anymore. The city centre has been wiped out by the blaze, with 13,000 buildings destroyed and 110,000 left homeless. The so-called 'Frankish quarter', containing the banking and insurance industries, has been destroyed. The National Bank of $COUNTRY$ and its reserves has also been destroyed. The government estimates the total damage caused to be 13 million gold pounds. The report contained a scathing review of the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ government, berating our lack of proper safety regulations, which they blamed the devastation on.
The horror!
The Future of Thessalonica

In the aftermath of the devastating fire, the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ government is being called to address the issue of Thessalonica's future. Three distinct factions have developed. The first calls for an international design competition to be held, aiming to take this opportunity to redesign the city and showcase the prestige of $COUNTRY$, as well as our commitment to Thessalonica and Macedonia in general. We could begin to think about making Thessalonica a city of international renown, home to world-class infrastructure.The second, the nationalist camp, wants the competition to only be open to $COUNTRY_ADJ$ architects. Critics say that this is likely to stifle creativity. The third camp, the so-called 'laissez-faire boys', are opposed to any government oversight of the city's redesign, which they say will likely take years, and want the city to start building immediately. Planners fear that while recovery might be quicker with the laissez-faire approach, the resulting city might become a Frankenstein.
An International Design Competition will be held.
We don't need any foreigners to tell us what Thessalonica should look like!
Let the people start building at once!
An International Design Competition

In the aftermath of the devastating fire in Thessalonica, the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ government has decided to hold an international design competition in order to redesign the city from scratch. The design brief is quite specific in some areas, but leaves a lot of room for creative interpretation. $COUNTRY$ has been invited to enter the competition and produce a vision for the city. There is a cash prize of £30,000 for the winning entry.
We shall enter.
Our architects can be put to better use domestically.
The Redesign of Thessalonica

The international committee of architects and urban planners overseeing the design competition for the redesign of the city of Thessalonica has chosen an entry by a team of $COUNTRY_ADJ$ architects as the winning design. The committee praised both the overall composition as well as the attention to detail, the decision to opt for a local Neo-Byzantine style, as well as the grandeur of places such as the new Civic Square and the Triumphal Arch. An underground Metropolitan Railway has also been proposed, as well as extensions to the port, a large university campus, public parks, and other staples of modern European-style city-planning previously absent from the city. The winning team has also taken special care to incorporate the city's numerous monuments into the urban fabric.
A Balkan Paris in the making.
Implementing the New Plan

Now that the International Committee has picked the winning design for the rebuilding of Thessalonica, the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ government must decide to what degree it is willing to finance it. While the drawings are impressive indeed, much of the infrastructure will need to be paid for by the national government. This is unlikely to be cheap, and we may have to abandon some of the more extravagant parts of the plan in favour of sensible economics.
The plan must be implemented in full.
We will keep the jist of it, do we really need so many statues?
The architectural plans are ludicrous, we could never afford this!
The New Thessalonica

Today marks a historic day in the history of Thessalonica, as the construction crews finished their rebuilding of the city. The Mayor, the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ $MONARCHTITLE$, foreign dignitaries, survivors of the fire, and thousands of civilians attended the handover ceremony at Alexander the Great square, the new focal point of the city. The city of Thessalonica, far from being mortally wounded by the devastation of the fire, has risen up like a phoenix and now stands proudly, more glorious than ever, a true metropolis worthy of $COUNTRY$. Her tree-lined boulevards, large public squares, imposing public architecture, and public transportation system make Thessalonica a world-class city.
Here's to another 2,300 years of glory!

A great day for all Thessalonians.

The Walls of Thessalonica

The city of Thessalonica has been surrounded by its ancient Byzantine walls, colloquially known as 'Ta Kastra', or 'The Castles', for nearly two thousand years. Once impenetrable, the walls have fallen into irrelevance as military technology has progressed. Nowadays, they serve no practical function. To the contrary, they block the city's direct access to the sea, and do not allow the north-south winds to blow through the dense urban fabric, causing the air to go stale. Demolishing the part of the walls running along the Thermaic Gulf would allow the city to grow by reclaiming land. The other parts of the walls will be retained.
About time!
Red Tower No More

Not long after the Ottoman Sultan Murad II captured the city of Thessalonica from Venice in 1430, instructions were given for the construction of a large tower and fortress in the city. For years, the Tower has loomed over the city as a testament of Ottoman authority. The Ottoman administration used the Tower as both a garrison and a prison, for which it gained the nickname 'the red tower' thanks to the blood stains running along its walls. Now that Thessalonica is no longer in ottoman hands, the local administration has paid a former Jewish prisoner to paint the tower white in exchange for his freedom, and the new White Tower has become the symbol of the city.
Isn't that beige...?
Philip's Legacy

In the classical era, Macedonia extended its control over of nearly all of the Greek mainland. But the Macedonian empire was short-lived and soon crumbled. Now, having reconquered what is rightfully ours, we can assume the legacy of Philip II.
Alexander's Legacy

By the time he died at age 30, Alexander the Great, son of Philip II, succeeded in conquering everything between Asia Minor and far-away India. With our rise among the Great Powers of the world, we can begin to think about rebuilding that empire - starting with the conquest of Ionia.
Align with the Yugoslavs

Thanks to our friendship with our Slavic neighbours to the north, a paradigm shift has occured in Macedonia and we are now able to abandon our absurd Greek roots in favour of the true powerhouse of the future - South Slavia!
Hegemonia

The creation of an independent Macedonia of both Greeks and Bulgars has given both ethnic groups equal rule over Macedonia. Many in government, however, hope that Macedonia may extend her just and noble influence over the rest of the Greek world as well. Now that an upstart state claiming to be 'Greece' has established itself, it is the duty of the Macedonian government to put our southern neighbours out of their misery and unify Greece under the Macedonian tricolour.
Ptolemaida Coal Rush
Ptolemaida is rich in coal, though unfortunately it's only lignite - the lowest grade of coal. The government is actively encouraging coal mining regardless.
A New Anabasis

Alexander the Great's Anabasis, or 'ascent', ushered-in an era of unprecedented power for the Greek world. Macedonia, now a Great Power of international renown, must take it upon herself to civilise the peoples of the Near East once more by accepting them into her warm embrace.
Reviving the Congress

Ancient Macedonia, much like the other states of the Greek north, had complex constitution. An important component of that political structure was the Synedrion, or Congress, an assembly of Macedonian nobles whose purpose was to advise the King. As instability spreads across Macedonia, perhaps it is time to consider reinstating a legislature.
Walls of Thessalonica Demolished
The section of the Walls of Thessalonica running along the Thermaic Gulf have been demolished, allowing the city to develop without the constraints of the ancient fortifications.
